author: Jonathan Walker
title: Tory leadership candidates challenged to guarantee North East investment
text:
Tory leadership candidates challenged to guarantee North East investment 18:30, 8 Jul 2016 By Jonathan Walker Region's MPs want to know if the North East will receive funding once UK quits the European Union Shares Get daily news by email PA/PA Wire Home Secretary Theresa May (left) and Andrea Leadsom are the two women vying to be Britain's next prime minister 
The two Conservative candidates hoping to become the nation’s next Prime Minister have been challenged to pledge that the North East will continue to receive investment once the UK quits the European Union . 
It comes after business leaders sought assurances from the Government over the delivery of EU funding to the region. 
Home Secretary Theresa May and energy minister Andrea Leadsom are standing in the contest to choose the next Tory leader and the winner will become Prime Minister. 
Nick Brown, MP for Newcastle East and a former minister for the North East, said they should explain how they would ensure the region continues to receive funding once EU cash dries up. 
And Grahame Morris , a member of the Labour shadow cabinet and MP for Easington, warned that the region was under-funded in comparison to the South East and London. 
The North East Local Enterprise Partnership (LEP) has committed £89.5m of EU structural funding to boost growth in the region, while a further £104.5m was submitted to the Government for approval in the run up to last month’s referendum. 
And LEP chair Andrew Hodgson, the chief executive officer of major manufacturer Soil Machine Dynamics, has revealed that the business-led organisation is lobbying Government for clarity and seeking assurances that any potential future funding gap will be filled. 
Mr Brown said: “All economies gravitate towards their centre and in the case of the United Kingdom that’s London and the south east. 
“It is the duty of government to take an active interest in regional policy and take measures to push back against this trend - for a number of reasons, including bearing down on congestion in London an dthe south east and making sure that opportunities and power are fairly distributed across the United Kingdom. The present government just isn’t doing so.” 
He added: “The most significant single regional policy in the North East was under the EU structural fund. 
“Will at least this funding stream continue under the new arrangements? That is the immediate question for the two candidates to be leader of the Conservative Party.” Read More North East LEP calls on Government to ensure multi-million EU funding 
And Mr Morris said: “It’s essential to secure investment for our region in the wake of the Brexit result. Because for our region it is £400m worth of European structural fund and for us that’s incredibly important, because that helps to drive and maintain jobs and economic growth in the North East. 
“The Government have got to address he regional imbalances in terms of capital investment in infrastructure in the regions. 
“If the Government is serious about encouraging growth and sharing prosperity it is vital to protect that funding, and in fact they should go further.” 
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn raised the issue of investment in the North East in the House of Commons this week as he accused David Cameron of breaking his promise to build a Northern Powerhouse and said just 50p in every £100 of investment goes to the North East. 
The Labour leader said: “This Government promised that they would rebalance our economy. They promised a Northern Powerhouse, yet half of 1% of infrastructure investment is going to the North East and London is getting 44 times more than that. 
“Is it not time to have a real rebalancing of our economy and to invest in the areas that are losing out so badly?”
